steps.title: Buy or collect 8 lbs of whole walnuts in the shell.
steps.content: Buy or collect 8 lbs of whole walnuts in the shell. These are your freshest option. The freshness of your walnuts will ultimately determine how much oil you will extract.

steps.title: Crack open the walnut.
steps.content: Crack open the walnut. Using a hinged nutcracker, place the whole nut between the two metal hinges and squeeze tightly.

steps.title: Remove the meat.
steps.content: Remove the meat. Separate the walnut meat from the shell, including the thin seed jacket. Don't worry about breaking the meat, as you will be grinding it in the next part.

steps.title: Place walnut meat in a bowl.
steps.content: Place walnut meat in a bowl. Collect your shelled walnuts in a bowl as you go, and throw out the shells.

steps.title: Prepare your grinder.
steps.content: Prepare your grinder. The walnuts should be ground using a meat grinder, a food processor, or even a Nutribullet, whichever you have access to. [1] X Research source When using a food processor or Nutribullet, make sure blades and nuts are at a cool room temperature before grinding. This will prevent overheating, and keep the nuts from turning into a paste. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Put a cup of walnuts at a time into your machine.
steps.content: Put a cup of walnuts at a time into your machine. It's important not to overfill food processors, as this will cause an uneven consistency during processing.

steps.title: Grind the walnuts.
steps.content: Grind the walnuts. “Pulse” grind your walnuts by turning your machine on for a couple of seconds and then off again.

steps.title: Repeat.
steps.content: Repeat. Continue the pulse method of grinding until your walnut meat is a fine nut meal consistency. Do not blend continuously, or the oils will release too soon. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Place ground walnuts in a clean bowl.
steps.content: Place ground walnuts in a clean bowl. After grinding a cup of the meat, put it aside in a bowl while continuing to grind the remaining walnuts.

steps.title: Pour the walnut meal into a pot.
steps.content: Pour the walnut meal into a pot. Pour your ground walnuts into a pot big enough for you to add water and still stir comfortably without spilling.

steps.title: Add water.
steps.content: Add water. Pour just enough water into the pot to cover walnut meat.

steps.title: Simmer for approximately 45 minutes.
steps.content: Simmer for approximately 45 minutes. While the mixture is heating, it needs to be stirred continuously. Once the moisture has evaporated, it is ready to be pressed.

steps.title: Learn your oil press.
steps.content: Learn your oil press. Every oil press is different. Some presses don't require the grinding step, while others don't require heating. Make sure you know what type of press you’ll be using in advance, and follow the instructions for your appliance.

steps.title: Place a clean bowl under your press.
steps.content: Place a clean bowl under your press. Have a clean container prepared to catch the oil as you’re pressing.

steps.title: Press the walnuts.
steps.content: Press the walnuts. Following the directions on your appliance, begin putting small amounts of the heated walnut meat into the press and squeeze until you get oil. [4] X Research source Once you’ve gone through all of your walnuts you should have approximately two quarts of oil , depending on the quality of your nuts.

steps.title: Rinse the cheesecloth.
steps.content: Rinse the cheesecloth. Run the cheesecloth under cold water to remove any lint that may be stuck.

steps.title: Place the cheesecloth inside a colander or funnel.
steps.content: Place the cheesecloth inside a colander or funnel. Shake open the cheesecloth and line the inside of your colander/funnel with it. The cheesecloth is doing the filtering, but the colander/funnel gives structure, making the process easier. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Place the funnel or colander over your pitcher.
steps.content: Place the funnel or colander over your pitcher. A pitcher will make it easier to dispense into bottles for storing.

steps.title: Pour the oil into the pitcher.
steps.content: Pour the oil into the pitcher. Take the bowl of oil you caught from the press and pour the oil through the cheesecloth colander/ funnel and into the pitcher. The cheesecloth will catch any debris remaining in the oil.

steps.title: Choose your bottles.
steps.content: Choose your bottles. Use small to medium sized brown or stainless steel bottles. These are better at protecting the oil from heat or damaging light. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Bottle the oil.
steps.content: Bottle the oil. Dispense the pitcher of oil into your chosen bottles.

steps.title: Seal the bottle.
steps.content: Seal the bottle. When you’ve filled a bottle, make sure to seal it to maintain freshness.

steps.title: Label the bottle.
steps.content: Label the bottle. Put the date of production on your bottles, so you always have a time reference when you use it.

steps.title: Refrigerate the oil.
steps.content: Refrigerate the oil. Refrigeration is the best step in prolonging the life of your walnut oil. Walnut oil will be fresh for about two to three months . [7] X Research source
